title-group.article-title: Crashworthiness optimization design of honeycomb sandwich panel based on factor screening

article-meta.aff: 1State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body, Hunan University, Changsha, Hunan, China
2College of Mechanical and Vehicle Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha, Hunan, China

author-notes.corresp: Xu Han, State Key laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body, Hunan University, Changsha, Hunan 410082, China. Email: hanxu@hnu.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This paper presents a crashworthiness robust optimization design of aluminum honeycomb sandwich panel with regular hexagonal core cell based on explicit finite element analysis. First, the crashworthiness of honeycomb sandwich panel and the bare honeycomb core are compared with each other in the aspects of specific energy absorption and peak crushing force. The comparative results show that honeycomb sandwich panel can absorb more energy than the bare honeycomb core, though the peak crushing force of honeycomb sandwich panel is larger. Then the factor screening experiments are carried out to find out variables that have significant effects on the crashworthiness of honeycomb sandwich panel. The ultimate purpose of factor screening experiments is to decrease the computational expense by reducing the number of design variables. Finally, the dual response surface method and the crossed array design are employed to formulate the complex robust optimization design problem. The regression expressions of specific energy absorption and peak crushing force are defined as the objective and constraint function respectively in the robust design of crashworthiness optimization.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Due to the excellent mechanical properties combined with high strength-to-weight ratio, sandwich panels are used increasingly in aerospace, automobile and marine industries [1]. The major usage of sandwich panels in automobiles is for the passenger protection. The sandwich panels are mainly applied on the body shell, pillars and along roof line as energy-absorption structures during a vehicle impact event [2,3]. Due to its broad use in these fields and aspects, research on the impact behavior and energy-absorption characteristics of honeycomb sandwich panel (HSP) has been increasingly popular.

Some researchers have investigated the impact behavior of composite sandwich panels through experiments and numerical simulations. Their studies mainly focused on the failure mechanisms, impact force, damage initiation and damage propagation of sandwich panels impacted by a solid, round-shaped or truncated cone impactor [4–6]. The failure response and characteristics of aluminum HSPs subjected to low-velocity impact have also been discussed in the past few years [7,8]. The HSPs are expected to absorb as much impact energy as possible during the crashing process so as to reduce the damage transmitted to the protective passengers. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate the energy-absorption characteristics of sandwich panels. Goldsmith and Sackman [9] described an experiment study of both bare honeycomb cores (HCs) and honeycomb sandwich plates under the impact loading of blunt strikers. Moriarty and Goldsmith [10] studied the energy absorption capabilities of sandwich plates with HCs and uniformly thick facings under conditions of nonperforating impact by a massive striker experimentally and found that samples with an aluminum core and thin face plates were the most efficient energy-absorbing combination. Zhou and Hill [11] examined the effects of the varying skin thickness, core density and core type, indenter nose shape and boundary conditions on the damage and energy-absorbing characteristics of HSP. Atli-Veltin and Gandhi [12] studied the in-plane crushing and energy absorption of sandwiched HCs with face sheets through finite element simulations. The effects of geometric parameters, such as face sheet thickness, cell wall length, wall thickness and core depth, on specific energy absorption (SEA), were also examined in their study. Generally speaking, the previous studies on the energy absorption of sandwich panels rarely involve optimization design.

In the crashworthiness optimization design of the vehicle body, surrogate models especially response surface models are adopted prevalently [13–19]. Their focuses are mainly on the mean value of response where variance is assumed to be small and constant. However, when the variances for all observations are not equal, classical response surface methodology can be misleading [20]. In this case, the dual response surface method is an alternative. This approach builds two models, one for the mean and one for the standard deviation. Vining and Myers [21] proposed a priority-based dual response optimization approach. They suggested optimizing a “primary response” while the “secondary response” is subjected to an appropriate constraint. Lin and Tu [22] proposed a mean square error (MSE) approach which aggregates the mean and standard deviation models into a single function. A number of other dual response optimization methods also have been put forward in the past two decades [20,23–25]. Shaibu and Cho [26] and Costa [27] have reviewed the approaches for optimizing dual response problems in the response surface method (RSM) framework. These methods have been successfully used for robust parameter design (RPD) in different application areas. Yeniay et al. [28] utilized the dual response surface approach to quantify variability in vehicle weight and size analysis during conceptual design phase of a launch vehicle. Sun et al. [29,30] have applied dual response surface method on crashworthiness design of vehicle and drawbead design in sheet metal forming.

Design of experiment (DoE) is an important part for the efficiency and accuracy of RS models. If there are too many variables, a large number of experimental points is needed to construct accurate RS models. Then the simulation-based optimization design would be very costly. Under this circumstance, factor screening experiments are very necessary to screen the sensitive factors so as to reduce the total number of design variables. Montgomery [31] indicated that 2k factorial design and two-level fractional factorial designs are widely used in factor screening experiments. So an unreplicated 25-1 design is used in this paper to select variables that have significant effects on the SEA and peak crushing force (Peak F).

The paper aims at finding out factors that have remarkable effects on the crashworthiness of HSP and exploring the robust design of aluminum sandwich panels with hexagonal core under the crashworthiness criteria with some functional and geometrical constraints. In this study, dual response surface method (DRSM) is adopted to construct the functions of the mean and standard deviation of SEA, and RSM is used to construct the model of Peak F. Meanwhile, the crashworthiness of HSP and the bare HC are compared with each other before the crashworthiness optimization design of HSP.

sec.title: The 2k factorial design
sec.p: The 2k factorial design is a two-level design of k factors and it is widely used in factor screening experiment [31]. It is also a complete factorial design for k factors with the smallest number of runs, where some high-order interactions are negligible. Because there are only two levels for each factor, we assume that the response is approximately linear over the range of the factor levels chosen, which has been verified to be a reasonable assumption in many factor screening experiments during the study of the process or system.

Sometimes only a single replica of the design is allowed to be run. When analyzing data from unreplicated factorial designs, Daniel [32] suggests examining a normal probability plot or half-normal plot of the estimates of the effects. The effects that are negligible will tend to fall along a straight line on this plot, whereas significant effects will not lie along the straight line. Thus, the preliminary model will be specified to contain those effects that are apparently nonzero, based on the normal or half-normal probability plot. The apparently negligible effects are combined as an estimate of error. The analysis procedure for a 2k design is listed in Table 1. Table 1.
Analysis procedure for a 2k design
Six steps of 2k design
1. Estimate factor effects
2. Form initial model
a. If the design is replicated, fit the full model
b. If there is no replication, form the model using a normal or half normal probability plot of the effects
3. Perform statistical testing. The analysis of variance is used to formally test for significance of main effects and interaction
4. Refine model
5. Analyze residuals to check for model adequacy
6. Interpret results

Factor effects and the sum of squares are respectively calculated as (1)AB…K=2n2k(ContrastAB…K), and (2)SSAB…K=1n2k(ContrastAB…K)2, where A,B,…,K represent the factors, n denotes the number of replicates and k is the number of factors. To estimate an effect or to compute the sum of squares for an effect, we should first determine the contrast associated with the effect which can be calculated by expanding the right-hand side of (3)ContrastAB…K=(a±1) (b±1)…(k±1).

In expanding equation (3), ordinary algebra is used with “1” being replaced by (1) in the final expression. The a, b, … , k and (1) are symbols used to represent the treatment combinations. The sign in each set of parentheses is negative if the factor is included in the effect and positive if the factor is not included. Each item of the expanded formula represents a treatment combination.
To illustrate the use of equation (3), consider a 23 factorial design. The contrast for AB will be (4)ContrastAB=abc+ab+c+1-ac-bc-a-b=abc+ab+c+(1)-ac-bc-a-b.
A computer software package is usually employed in the statistical analysis of the factorial design.

sec.title: Dual response surface method
sec.p: The liner, quadratic, cubic or quartic polynomial functions are typically used to develop approximate model that provides explicit relationship between design variables and responses. The DRSM allows constructing two models: one for the mean and another for the standard deviation [33]. The approximations to the mean and standard deviation of the structural responses are as (5){y~μ=∑i=1Maiϕi(x)y~σ=∑j=1Nbjψj(x) where M and N, respectively, represent the number of basis functions ϕi(x) and ψj(x), ai(i=1,…,M) and bj(j=1,…,N) are the unknown coefficients, x denotes the design variables. By taking a quadratic polynomial dual RS model for an example [21], the approximate expression can be given as (6){y~μ=a0+∑i=1naixi+∑i<jnaijxixj+∑i=1naiixi2y~σ=b0+∑i=1nbixi+∑i<jnbijxixj+∑i=1nbiixi2

To determine the unknown coefficients a=(a1,a2,…,aM) and b=(b1,b2,…,bN), a number of design sampling points x(i)(i=1,2,…,Q) are needed (Q>M and Q>N). After the finite element analysis (FEA) results yμ=[yμ(1),yμ(2),…,yμ(Q)]Tand yσ=[yσ(1),yσ(2),…,yσ(Q)]T are obtained at these selected Q sampling points, the least-square method then can be adopted to get the unknown coefficients a and b by minimizing the total squared errors between the analysis and approximations [31]. The total squared errors at Q selected sampling points are computed by (7){Eμ(a)=∑k=1Qɛμk2=∑k=1Q[yμ(k)-∑i=1Maiϕi(x(k))]2Eσ(b)=∑k=1Qɛσk2=∑k=1Q[yσ(k)-∑j=1Nbiψi(x(k))]2

By minimizing Eμ(a) and Eσ(b) in equation (7), the coefficients vectors of the dual RS model are obtained as (8){a=(ϕμTϕμ)-1(ϕμTyμ)b=(ψσTψσ)-1(ψσTyσ) where ϕμ and ψσ denote the matrix consisting of basis functions evaluated at these Q sampling points, which are respectively given as (9)ϕμ=[ϕ1(x(1))…ϕM(x(1))::ϕ1(x(Q))…ϕM(x(Q))],ψσ=[ψ1(x(1))…ψN(x(1))::ψ1(x(Q))…ψN(x(Q))].

The numerical errors in the dual RS model can be caused by the selection of basis function, sampling points and the least square. In order to validate the fitness accuracy of the surrogate model, the relative error (RE) of FEA results [15,16] can be evaluated as (10)RE=y(x)-y~(x)y(x) where y(x) represents the FEA solution, y~(x) denotes the result of mean or standard deviation response from the dual RS model.

Meanwhile, statistical analysis techniques such as analysis of variance (ANOVA) [14,31] can be used to check the fitness of an RS model and to identify the effects of design variables. They indicated that the major statistical parameter used for evaluating model fitness are the F statistic, R2, adjusted R2(Radj2) and root mean square error (RMSE). These parameters are calculated as (11)F=(SST-SSE)/pSSE/(Q-p-1), (12)R2=1-SSE/SST, (13)Radj2=1-(1-R2)Q-1Q-p-1, (14)RMSE=SSEQ-p-1, where p is the number of nonconstant terms in the RS model, SSE and SST are the sum of squared errors and the total sum of squares, respectively, calculated as (15)SSE=∑i=1Q(yi-y~i)2,SST=∑i=1Q(yi-y¯i)2, where y¯i is the mean value of FEA results yi.

Note that these parameters are not totally independent of each other. Generally speaking, the larger the values of R2 and Radj2, and the smaller the value of RMSE, the better the fit. When the number of design variables is large, it is more appropriate to look at Radj2, because R2 always increases as the increase of number of terms in the model, while Radj2 actually decreases if unnecessary terms are added to the model [14,31].

sec.title: Definition of crashworthiness optimization problem
sec.p: A general constrained single-objective crashworthiness optimization problem can be formulated as (16){Minimize:y=-SEA(x)s.t.Peak F(x)≤Const.xL≤x≤xU where x=(x1,x2,…,xk) denotes the vector of k design variables, xL=(x1L,x2L,…,xkL) and xU=(x1U,x2U,…,xkU) are, respectively, the lower and upper bounds of the design variables [15]. If the perturbation induced by parameter uncertainties is taken into consideration, this formulation can be formulated as (17){Minimize:y=f(SEAμ(x),SEAσ(x))s.t.PeakFμ(x)≤Const.xL≤x≤xU where SEAμ(x) and SEAσ(x) are the mean and standard deviation of SEA, PeakFμ(x) is the mean of Peak F.

The optimization method for dual response problem proposed by Lin and Tu [22] is employed in this study. The design aims to maximize the response mean and thus the objective function is formulated as (18)f(SEAμ(x),SEAσ(x))=-ωSEAμ2(x)+(1-ω)SEAσ2(x) where ω denotes the weight to emphasis either mean or standard deviation.

sec.title: Comparison between HSP and bare HC
Definition of compared models
sec.p:
The basic construction of the studied HSP is shown in Figure 1 and the shape of each core cell is regular hexagon (Figure 2). t, L, Hc, Hf1, Hf2, a and b, respectively, denotes cell wall thickness, cell width, core height, top face sheet thickness, back face sheet thickness, HSP length and HSP width. The geometrical parameters of compared HSP and bare HC are given as t=0.1mm,L=10mm, Hc=100mm,Hf1=Hf2=1mm,a=103.92mm and b=90mm. The HSP and bare HC are taken into account under the same out-of-plane impact loading condition, as depicted in Figure 3, where the HSP or bare HC is put on the rigid floor and impacted by a 100-kg rigid plate with a velocity of 10 m/s. The degrees of freedom of back face sheet or the bottom of bare HC are all constrained to avoid sliding between rigid wall and HSP or bare HC. Figure 1.
Honeycomb sandwich panel. Figure 2.
A honeycomb-core cell. Figure 3.
Schematic view of simulation.

The face sheets and HC are made of Al-2024 aluminum alloy [34] and 5052-0 aluminum alloy [7], respectively. They are defined as bilinear, isotropic, plastic materials, the properties of which are presented in Table 2. Since the aluminum is insensitive to the strain rate, this effect is neglected in the FE modeling [35]. Table 2.
Material properties for aluminum sandwich panels
Property Face sheets (Al-2024 aluminum alloy) Core (5052-0 aluminum alloy)
ρ(kg/m3) 2700 2685
E (GPa) 72.4 69.6
ET (GPa) 28 2.5
σy (MPa) 75.8 65.5
ν 0.33 0.33

In this study, Belytschko-four-node shell element is used to model face sheets and the HC. The adhesive bonding between the core and face sheets and also the core itself is assumed to be perfect, and node-to-node constraint is adopted at the face sheets-core interface. The attached walls of HC is simulated to be single layers and they are two times thickness of the single layer wall in our study. Automatic surface-to-surface contacts between the moving rigid plate and HSP or bare HC are defined, and meanwhile, a single surface contact algorithm is utilized to consider the self-contact of core elements. The FE models are generated by ANSYS Parametric Design Language (APDL), and the rigid floor and rigid plate are given by using the internal rigid-wall feature in LS-DYNA [36].

sec.title: Comparative results and discussion
sec.p:
The HSP and bare HC are compared with each other in crushing strength, energy-absorption ability and deformation pattern. The following results could be concluded from the comparative study:
As shown in Figure 4, the bare HC began to be densified at about 6 ms, whereas densification of the core of HSP started at 8 ms. The delay of densification is of great practical significance. That means the dramatic increase of the crushing force during the densification will be delayed. It is very clear in Figure 4 that there is a large increase in crushing strength of HSP compared to bare HC. This is related to the stabilizing effect of the face sheets [6,37]. However, the Peak F of HSP is much larger than bare HC, as listed in Table 3.
On the given crushing condition, the face sheets barely absorb any energy during the crushing process. Therefore, the absorbed energy-time history curve of HSP is coincident with the one of HSP-Core. However, the core of HSP could absorb much more energy than bare HC, as shown in Figure 5, and this is also because of the stabilizing effect of the face sheets. The SEA of HSP is also greater than bare HC (as listed in Table 3), so we could say that the energy-absorption efficiency of the studied HSP is better than bare HC.
Due to the effect of face sheets, the plastic buckling processes of HSP and bare HC are different from each other. The buckling of bare HC is found to initiate from the upper impacted edge and progressively move downward. However, in the core of HSP, the folding of cell walls appears at both ends initially. Then the cell walls fold from bottom to top progressively in the following crushing process. They both deform axisymmetrically in a stable pattern, as shown in Figure 6.
Table 3.
The crashworthiness data of compared HSP and bare HC
Peak F (kN) Total absorbed energya (kJ) Mass (kg) SEA (kJ/kg)
HSP 52.915 1.24542 89.171 E-3 13.96665
Bare HC 11.093 0.360354 38.664 E-3 9.320143
HC: honeycomb core; HSP: honeycomb sandwich panel; SEA: specific energy absorption. a
The internal energy of HSP or bare HC before densification is taken as the total absorbed energy.
Figure 4.
Force-time history curves of honeycomb sandwich panel (HSP) and bare honeycomb core (HC). Figure 5.
Absorbed energy-time history curves of honeycomb sandwich panel (HSP), bare honeycomb core (HC) and HSP-Core (the core of HSP). Figure 6.
The longitudinal deformation patterns of bare honeycomb core (HC) and honeycomb sandwich panel (HSP) (Red part—attached walls, green part—single layer walls).

sec.title: Factor screening experiments
sec.p:
In order to find out variables that have significant effects on the crashworthiness of HSP, a 25–1 design is used for sampling in the factor screening experiment. The two levels of five factors are listed in Table 4, and the construction of 25–1 design is shown in Table 5. We expect this 25–1 design to provide excellent information concerning the main effects and two-factor interactions. Coded design variables –1 ≤ xi ≤ 1 are used in the analysis of the factorial design. > Table 4.
Five factors and their values of −1 and +1 levels
Analysis Factors Dimensional Parameters (shown in Figure 1 and Figure 2) −1 level +1 level
A Cell wall thickness (t) 0.02 mm 0.10 mm
B Cell width (L) 4.0 mm 10.0 mm
C Core height (Hc) 20.0 mm 100.0 mm
D Back face sheet thickness (Hf2) 0.50 mm 2.0 mm
E Top face sheet thickness (Hf1) 0.50 mm 2.0 mm
Table 5.
Construction of the 25–1 design

3 −1 1 −1 −1 −1 b 2.885112 10.38707

SEA: specific energy absorption.

The ratio of maximum to minimum SEA is 91.7938, and the maximum peak force to minimum peak force is 44.328. They are so large that a logarithmic transformation y* = lg y is applied before analyzing the 25–1 design [31]. Table 6 contains the effect estimates, sum of squares and percent contribution for the 15 effects from this experiment. Table 6.

sec.title: Select influential factors for SEA
sec.p:
Figure 7 presents a normal probability plot of the effect estimates of SEA from this experiment. The main effects of A, B, D and E are large. Because of aliasing, these effects are really A + BCDE, B + ACDE, D + ABCD and E + ABCD. However, it seems plausible that higher interactions are negligible, we could conclude that only A, B, D and E are important effects. The following model could be formed based on the normal probability plot, (19)y∧=lg∧(SEA)=0.78672+0.39642t-0.23397L-0.12150Hf2-0.14722Hf1 here in this equation t, L, Hf2 and Hf1 are normalized. Figure 7.
Normal probability plot of effects following log transformation— specific energy absorption (SEA).

The ANOVA for this model is summarized in Table 7. The sum of squares of this model is SSModel=SSA+SSB+SSD+SSE=3.9733, and it explains about 94.84% of the variability in the SEA. Table 7.
Analysis of variance for the model of SEA
Source of squares Sum of squares Degrees of freedom Mean square F value p Value
A-t 2.5144 1 2.5144 127.8760 <0.0001
B-L 0.8759 1 0.8759 44.5443 <0.0001
D-Hf2 0.2362 1 0.2362 12.0120 0.0053
E-Hf1 0.3468 1 0.3468 17.6358 0.0015
Residual 0.2163 11 0.0197
Total 4.1896 15
SEA: specific energy absorption.

As shown in Figure 8, the points on normal probability plot of residuals lie reasonably close to a straight line. The plot of residuals versus the predicted SEA does not reveal any obvious pattern (Figure 9). The two plots both support the conclusion that A (cell wall thickness t), B (cell width L), D (back face sheet thickness Hf2) and E (top face sheet thickness Hf1) have significant effects on SEA. Figure 8.
Normal probability plot of residuals following log transformation (specific energy absorption (SEA)). Figure 9.
Plot of residuals versus the predicted specific energy absorption (SEA) following log transformation.

sec.title: Select influential factors for Peak F
sec.p:
Following the same method as selecting variables that have significant effects on SEA, it is found that A (cell wall thickness t) and B (cell width L) are influential variables for Peak F. The normal probability plot of the effect estimates of Peak F is shown in Figure 10. Figure 10.
Normal probability plot of effects following log transformation-peak crushing force.

In general, the cell wall thickness, cell width, top and back face sheet thickness have remarkable effects on the crashworthiness of HSP. While the estimated effects of top and back face sheet thickness for SEA are almost the same (Table 6), they are considered to be one variable in the following study, i.e. Hf1=Hf2=Hf.

sec.title: Robust design for HSP under crashworthiness criterion
Response surface models
sec.p: The least-square method is used to determine the coefficients of the cubic dual RS models for SEA. The expressions of RS SEAμ(L,t,Hf) and SEAσ(L,t,Hf) are in equations (A1) and (A2) of Appendix A.

As previously referred, the Peak F is mainly determined by cell width L and cell wall thickness t. Hence, the RS model of PeakFμ is a polynomial function of L and t, as shown in equation (A3) of Appendix A.

The accuracy of these RS models are evaluated by R2, Radj2, RMSE and RE. The values of RE at each sampling point are listed in Table 9. Values of the other measures are listed in Table 10. Obviously, the accuracy of the RS models is adequate and allows us to carry out the design optimization properly. The RSs of SEA_\mu and PeakFμ with respect to design variables L and t are plotted in Figure 11. Table 10.
Accuracy of different RS models
SEAμ SEAσ PeakFμ
R2 0.9994 0.9949 0.9929
Radj2 0.9945 0.9536 0.9639
RMSE 0.2199 0.0130 2.9011
RMSE: root mean square error; Peak F: peak crushing force; SEA: specific energy absorption.
Figure 11.
The response surfaces of specific energy absorption (SEA) and peak crushing force (Peak F): (a) RS of SEA and (b) RS of Peak F.

sec.title: Optimization with constraint of the Peak F
sec.p: After the RSs of the objective and constraint functions are constructed, the optimization problem is defined as (20){Minimize:y=f(SEAμ(L,t,Hf),SEAσ(L,t,Hf))s.t.PeakFμ(L,t)≤70kN4≤L≤100.03≤t≤0.090.5≤Hf≤2.0 where f(SEAμ(L,t,Hf),SEAσ(L,t,Hf))=-ωSEAμ2(L,t,Hf)+(1-ω)SEAσ2(L,t,Hf) and the constraint of PeakFμ(L,t) is set as 70kN [38]. The limits of PeakFμ(L,t) could be adjusted according to practical considerations.

The single-objective constrained optimization problem is solved by using the constrained nonlinear optimization algorithm provided by MATLAB. The optimal solutions of equation (20) are listed in Table 11 when ω=0.01, ω=0.05 and ω=0.1. The value of ω can be changed according to design requirements. With a view to manufacturing techniques, the optimal design of HSP is considered to be L=6.0mm, t=0.08mm and Hf=0.50mm. The corresponding values of SEA and Peak F by RSM and FEA are listed in Table 12. The relative errors (REs) of SEA and Peak F between RSM and FEA are both less than 5%. The optimal result is thought to be reasonable, thought the obtained Peak F is a little larger than 70kN. Table 11.
Optimal solution of equation (23)
ω L (mm) t (mm) Hf (mm)
0.01 5.8601 0.0766 0.5
0.05 5.9636 0.0805 0.5
0.1 5.9733 0.0809 0.5
Table 12.
Optimal results of HSP under the Peak F constraint (70 kN)
SEA (kJ/kg) Peak F (kN)
L (mm) t (mm) Hf (mm) RSM FEA RE (%) RSM FEA RE (%)
6 0.08 0.5 18.8742 19.1308 1.341 69.2777 72.9081 4.979
FEA: finite element analysis; HC: honeycomb core; HSP: honeycomb sandwich panel; SEA: specific energy absorption; RSM: response surface method.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This paper presents the crashworthiness design of HSPs that are impacted laterally by using the nonlinear finite element code LS-DYNA and design optimization techniques. The following conclusions can be drawn from the study.

The comparison of crashworthiness between HSP and bare HC shows that HSP can absorb more impact energy during the crushing process, but the Peak F is larger than bare HC due to the stabilizing effect of face sheets.

Under the given crushing condition, cell width, cell wall thickness and face sheet thickness are proven to have significant effects on the SEA of HSP through a fractional factorial design which is an efficient method for screening experiments.

After the factors that have remarkable effects on the crashworthiness of HSP are found, the HSP is optimized with the significant factors as design variables. Crossed design array and response surface methods including dual and conventional RSM are employed to construct the response surfaces of SEA and Peak F. At the same time, the uncertainties of parameters are taken into consideration. After the fitness of response surfaces are validated, a single-objective constrained optimization problem is established with the function of SEA as objective and Peak F as constraint. Finally, the optimal design is obtained as L=6.0mm, t=0.08mm and Hf=0.5mm.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The financial supports from National Natural Science Foundation of China (10902036), National 973 Project of China (2010CB832705) and the self-sponsored project (61075003) from State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body of Hunan University are gratefully acknowledged. Moreover, the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities, Hunan University is also gratefully acknowledged.
